abstractive.text: Two main options were discussed as to the organisation of the collected data.

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: and <vocalsound> the main thing that I was gonna ask people to help with today is <pause> to give input on what kinds of database format we should <pause> use in starting to link up things like word transcripts and annotations of word transcripts ,
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: Th - there are sort of two choices .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: On the one hand, a bespoke XML structure that connects transcriptions and annotations (down to the word-level) to a common timeline.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: I mean , we <disfmarker> I sort of already have developed an XML format for this sort of stuff .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: So tha it has a single time - line ,
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: I think for word - level , this would be OK .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: Its advantages are that it is easier to read, parse, map onto the Transcriber format and to expand with extra features.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: and I thought it was better if you 're looking at a raw file to be <disfmarker> t for the tags to say " it 's an utterance " , as opposed to the tag to say " it 's a link " .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: One of them is that it 's easy to parse .
extractive.label: s^df

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: Can you <disfmarker> But you can add to those structures if you <disfmarker>
extractive.label: s^bu.%--

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: The other thing <disfmarker> the other way that I sort of established this was as easy translation to and from the Transcriber format .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: Phone-level analysis can be included in the same structure, or in a separate, linked file.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: So I think it <disfmarker> it 's debatable whether you want to do phone - level in the same thing .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: The respective frame-level representation can be handled by P-files, a technology developed at ICSI, which also comes with a library of tools.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: or <disfmarker> or any frame - level stuff I would use P - file .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: It 's ICS uh , ICSI has a format for frame - level representation of features .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: And we have a lot of tools already to deal with it .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: I mean , it 's something that we developed at ICSI .
extractive.label: s^df^nd

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: But , I mean , it is just something we developed at ICSI .
extractive.label: s^df

abstractive.text: Separation of levels of analysis makes files more compact and manageable.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: More compact ,
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: XML standards offer libraries that can be used for the development of search tools.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: There 's a <pause> standard again in XML , specifically for searching XML documents <disfmarker> structured X - XML documents , where you can specify both the content and the structural position .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: It 's <disfmarker> it 's <disfmarker> you would use that to build your tool to do that sort of search .
extractive.label: s^df

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: What you would do is , someone would build a tool that used that as a library .
extractive.label: s^e

abstractive.text: On the other hand, the ATLAS (NIST) technology offers a very similar, but more generic organisational scheme based on nodes and links.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: which was their file format is just nodes and links ,
extractive.label: s^e

abstractive.text: These are labeled with domain specific types, like "utterance" or "speaker".

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: and then " type " would be " utterance " .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: This option offer well-developed infrastructure and flexibility as to the type of data storage (flat XML files or relational database).

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: they 're developing a big infrastructure .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: Um , and apparently they 've also developed a lot of tools ,
extractive.label: fh|s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: One of the things that ATLAS is doing is they 're trying to define an API which is independent of the back store ,
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: so that , uh , you could define a single API and the <disfmarker> the storage could be flat XML files or a database .
extractive.label: s^df

abstractive.text: In either case, it is important for the chosen format to allow for fast searches, flexible updates and, if possible, be reusable in future work.

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: But I thought it would be good to get something that we can <disfmarker> that other people can use or adopt for their own kinds of encoding .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: And so I wanted something where <pause> all of this can be done in a elegant way
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: and that if somebody wants to try something or compute something else , that it can be done flexibly .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: In order to confirm the suitability of the data format provided by the ATLAS project, its current state of development will be investigated.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: We should look at ATLAS ,
extractive.label: s^cs

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: Maybe I should .
extractive.label: s^cs

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: So I 'll <disfmarker> I 'll take a closer look at it .
extractive.label: s^cc

abstractive.text: More specifically, the issues that have to be ascertained are, firstly, whether the external file representation offers a format that would be appropriate for speech data, and, secondly, how the linking between the different annotations (eg, between word-level representations and prosodic-feature structures) can be achieved.

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: Do they already have something that 's <disfmarker> that would be useful for us in place ?
extractive.label: qy^rt

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: Well , I think I 'm <disfmarker> I think w I had better look at it again
extractive.label: s^cs

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: but I 'm forgetting the exact level of nesting .
extractive.label: s^no

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: I mean , I have to look at it again to see whether it can really do what we want ,
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: Regardless of the actual format, however, there was consensus that keeping levels of analysis (words, phones, frames, etc) on separate, inter-linked files can make their management easier.

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: It seems to me you want to keep the frame - level stuff separate .
extractive.label: s^bs

abstractive.text: Choosing a project-specific format for the representation of the data might not be optimal for future work.

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: I <disfmarker> I think if it 's conceptually close , and they already have or will have tools that everybody else will be using , I mean , <vocalsound> it would be crazy to do something s you know , separate that <disfmarker>
extractive.label: s.%--

abstractive.text: On the other hand, it is not yet clear whether a more standardised, but generic technology, like that of the ATLAS project, can accommodate all the requirements of speech analysis.

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: Do they already have something that 's <disfmarker> that would be useful for us in place ?
extractive.label: qy^rt

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: Um , th what would <disfmarker> would <disfmarker> would <disfmarker> what would worry me is that maybe we might miss a little detail
extractive.label: h|s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: I mean , I have to look at it again to see whether it can really do what we want ,
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: Regardless of the particular format, including all annotations (sentences, words, phones, frames, etc) in one file could result in unmanageable file sizes.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: For lower than word - level , you 're talking about so much data that I just <disfmarker> I don't know .
extractive.label: s^no

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: These are big files .
extractive.label: s^na

abstractive.text: Even P-files, which are only for frame-level annotation, may be too verbose for the amount of data resulting from hour-long recordings.

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: I mean these are long meetings
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: But I think , a anything at frame - level , even P - file , is too verbose .
extractive.label: s^ba

abstractive.text: The actual mapping of word-level transcriptions to frame-level representations is expected to be problematic anyway.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: No matter what format you choose , you 're gonna have the trou you 're gonna have the difficulty of relating the <disfmarker> the frame - level features <disfmarker>
extractive.label: s^df

abstractive.text: Likewise, problems will arise if, in the future, slightly different transcripts of the same data are annotated in formats that do not include time-marks.

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: And sometimes the word sequences even differ slightly because they were edited s at one place but not the other .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: But , see , if you 'd annotate dialogue acts , you don't necessarily want to <disfmarker> or topics <disfmarker> you don't really want to be dealing with time - marks .
extractive.label: s^ng

abstractive.text: Trying to merge such annotations later will not be easy, because of the combination of transcription discrepancies with the loss of the underlying connection offered by the time-marks.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: The hard part is specifying what you mean by " merge " .
extractive.label: s^df

abstractive.text: An XML scheme to build representations of the data is already available.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: I mean , we <disfmarker> I sort of already have developed an XML format for this sort of stuff .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: It incorporates information regarding utterances, sentences, speakers, words, etc.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: And then somewhere la further down you might have something like an utterance tag
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: there 's a spea speaker tag up at the top which identifies them
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: All these features are linked together via time-marks that slot into a single, common timeline.

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: So tha it has a single time - line ,
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: And then you have a bunch of times .
extractive.label: s

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: And then , <nonvocalsound> I also wanted to <disfmarker> to be i to be able to not specify specifically what the time was and just have a stamp .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: This format also allows for linking to different levels of representation of the same data.

extractive.speaker: F
extractive.text: That you could call <disfmarker> that you would tie into this representation with like an ID .
extractive.label: s^bu

extractive.speaker: C
extractive.text: Or <disfmarker> or there 's a <disfmarker> there 's a particular way in XML to refer to external resources .
extractive.label: s

abstractive.text: For the frame-level representation, P-files is a readily available technology, developed at ICSI.

extractive.text: or <disfmarker> or any frame - level stuff I would use P - file .

extractive.text: It 's ICS uh , ICSI has a format for frame - level representation of features .
